By James Clay

By Gracie Daw

Action on 21, 22, 23, 27, 28 February and 1 and 2 March will not go ahead

YUSU Election Results 2023

By James Clay

Pierrick Roger re-elected as YUSU President

New bus service for Fishergate and Fulford

A new number 27 bus service will be introduced serving those in Fishergate and Fulford

YUSU prepare for cost of implementing Living Wage

YUSU have decided to explore the true cost of the Living Wage proposal in anticipation of the referendum on the issue, but there are concerns on how the proposal could be funded.

Proportion of state school admissions lowest since 2004

The percentage of state-educated undergraduates admitted to the University is at its lowest since 2004, but still higher than other Russell Group institutions.

Q&A: the new VC on salaries, carbon emissions, and semesterisation

We put the big questions to Professor Koen, the incoming Vice Chancellor

Students respond to University Semesterisation plans

The results have demonstrated a clear preference for the current term structure

YUSU act after scurvy diagnosis in Langwith

YUSU and college JCRCs are promoting healthy eating after cases of scurvy were reported among students

York hit with 'criminal' funding cut for teaching

The University has suffered a huge cut in HEFCE funding, but fared better than many of its peers

Taylor supports busker's street performance campaign

YUSU President comes out in support of a York busker's campaign to support street performance culture.

Koen Lamberts named new Vice-Chancellor

The University has announced the appointment of Professor Koen Lamberts as its new Vice-Chancellor

Police criticised by Claudia Lawrence's mother

By James Bithell

The mother of missing University Chef, Claudia Lawrence, has criticised North Yorkshire police for "trashing" the name of her daughter.

York student convicted for frying hamster

The Politics and International Relations student has been sentenced to 120 hours of community service, with a fine of PS1000 in court costs

Improvements for Hes East Bus Service

An additional 12am late service will run to town for club nights, as well as a late night library shuttle bus for students on Hes East during the exams and assessment period

YUSU RAG 'RAG Week' raises PS10,137.43

The week involved RAG hosting an array of events including bringing the student favourite 'Willow' to Hes East, Mr and Mrs York, Take Me Out, Blagathon and a Barn Dance.

'Carefree' and 'misleading' approach to porter service

By James Bithell

The University's approach to portering has been described by YUSU as cost-cutting and misleading

Horsemeat lasagne withdrawn late from Costcutter

The University of York's Costcutter at Market Square was found selling beef lasagne that contains traces of horsemeat, two days after it was withdrawn by Birds Eye.

Contractors fly drones for US and UK military

By James Bithell

A Nouse investigation has found BAE, York drone research sponsor, to be employing private, civilian contractors to fly drones for military operations in Afghanistan

CIA drone attacks branded "illegal" in US House of Representatives Hearing

"Under the legal theories adopted by our government in prosecuting Guantanamo detainees, these CIA officers as well as any higher level government officials who have authorized or directed their attacks are committing war crimes."

New YUSU presence for Heslington East

A new YUSU building will be on Heslington East by 2015, the University has announced.

Student Union election results

Kallum Taylor was re-elected as YUSU President on Friday night along with the new Union Officer team.

Medics caught in marking chaos

Medical students who received their Situational Judgement Test (STJ) marks on Monday 25 February may have received the wrong grades and potentially jeopardising placement offers.

Council cuts to hit students significantly

The City of York Council budget for 2013/2014 has been announced, with students due to face significant hits.

Students protest against cuts

Over one hundred York residents, including dozens of students, protested outside the City's Guildhall on the evening of 28th February

Grade rescaling denied for exam with missing questions

A disabled student has been refused a grade rescaling through mitigating circumstances after reporting that her specially-sized exam paper had a question missing.

Health centre increases services

Patient feedback has led to the Practice opening until 8pm three nights a week, a stay and wait clinic running on Friday afternoons, registration events on Heslington East and events on Saturdays and Sundays.

Maths resit after exam complaint

A number of students in the Mathematics department have been forced to resit a module after a professor unknowingly revealed the problem sets prior to the exam.

Marathon URY radio show

On March 8 the longest radio show in the history of URY Radio will kick off, hosted by Tom Edwards and Will Chalk. The show will run for 40 hours nonstop, starting at 7am on Friday 8th March, and running until 11pm on Saturday 9th.

University in military drone research

By James Bithell

Research includes detection of hiding enemies, battlefield communications and stealth technology

Showcase of International Human Rights Campaigners

By James Bithell

Eight international human rights defenders spoke about their experiences as "Women of the Front Line" in recognition of International Women's Day this Saturday

You probably know the results but why not listen to what your newly elected Sabbs had to say after their victories.
